Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, CAS Beijing 100190 PR China BaCO3-CeO2 composite catalysts were prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis method, and the influence of Ba/Ce on the structural and catalytic performance for selective oxidation of cyclohexane with molecule oxygen was studied. The characterization results exhibited that the doping amount of BaCO3 would influence the morphology, the content of surface Ce3+ and surface oxygen species (Oβ), and alkalinity. Meanwhile, the amount of alkali is the key to the decomposition of cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide (CHHP). 10.5% conversion of cyclohexane and 85.0% selectivity of KA oil were achieved under the reaction conditions of 1.0 MPa O2 and 150 °C for 2 h. The excellent catalytic activity was attributed to its high atomic ratios of Ce3+/Cetotal and Oβ/Ototal on the surface and optimal redox capacity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cyclohexane oxidation BaCO3-CeO2 composite KA oil CHHP decomposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanol (A) and cyclohexanone (K), referred to as KA oil, is one of the most essential oxidation reactions of sp3 C-H bonds in saturated hydrocarbons [1]. KA oil is a crucial intermediates for the production of nylon-6 and nylon-6,6. At present, in order to achieve relatively high selectivity of KA oil (75–80%) [2], the industrial oxidation of cyclohexane can only be at the expense of conversion. Therefore, the conversion of cyclohexane is generally lower than 5% [3]. The phenomenon is related to the reaction characteristics of cyclohexane oxidation. High C-H bond energy leads to difficulty in cyclohexane activation and the decomposition of CHHP to obtain KA oil requires breaking the O-O bond. Inhibiting the cleavage of C-C bond can reduce the production of deep oxidation products [4]. In the past few decades, the catalysts used for the selective oxidation of cyclohexane mainly include metals and metal oxides [5,6], molecular sieves [7,8], carbon materials [9,10], MOFs [11,12], etc. Among them, transition metal and composite metal oxide catalysts has attracted extensive attention of researchers because of its efficient and cost-effective characteristic. Zhang [6] reported that 17.7% of cyclohexane conversion with 81.0% of KA oil selectivity was achieved over the MnCeOx solid solutions, which was prepared by BmimTf2N in acetonitrile. Actually, developing excellent catalysts is the key to achieving the present challenge through a variety of design strategies. To improve the activation ability of C-H bond, researchers have typically used variable valence metal oxides, such as CeO2 [13,14], CoOx [15], VOx [16] and MnOx [17], to promote the formation of oxygen vacancies enhanced catalytic activity. Among these catalytic materials, cerium-based catalysts have been actively investigated as an exceptional oxygen promoter, carrier or stabilizer for cyclohexane oxidation owing to the reversible Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs, adjustable oxygen vacancy defects and surface acid-base properties [18]. Single CeO2, doping CeO2 with other metals oxides or immobilized it on the supports to decrease the energy barrier for oxygen vacancy formation, promote lattice oxygen mobility and oxygen activation has been applied comprehensively [19,20], such as Ce0.5Mn0.5Ox solid solution [6], 1% CeMnWO4 [21], Ce/AlPO-5 [22], CeCr/NC-500 [10] and so on [23,24]. In addition, cerium oxides with various particle sizes and shapes have been used for decomposing CHHP to deoxidize cyclohexane [25]. DFT study shows the direct decomposition of CHHP occurs on the CeO2 (111) in larger particles (Ce40O80) generated more A, while low coordinated Ce4+ Lewis acid sites presenting in small CeO2 nanoparticles (Ce21O42) preferentially formed more K. In the past several years, Ba, the most active element in alkaline-earth metals, has been used to prepare catalysts for the C-H bond of hydrocarbons oxidation [26]. For instance, BaO-MnOx was synthesized by the mechanochemical method for CH4 catalytic combustion [27]. Compared with the pure MnOx, BaO-MnOx compound oxide catalyst showed higher catalytic performance. The adding of appropriate amount of BaO into MnOx improves the redox capacity and oxygen mobility, which is beneficial to provide active oxygen substances. BaO-modified Pd/Al2O3 exhibits higher catalytic efficiency than Pd/Al2O3 for C3H8 oxidation [28]. The electron-withdrawing effect of BaO maintain Pd at high oxidation state, leading to a higher PdO content than Pd/Al2O3. Thus, Ba plays a certain role in the modification of metal oxides. Inspired by above considerations, in this work, we report the fabrication of a series of BaCO3-CeO2 composites with different Ba and Ce ratios. The detailed effects of the BaCO3 amount were systematically characterized by a variety of techniques. After the formation of the BaCO3-CeO2 composite, the composition, morphology, redox property, Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) and alkalinity of the CeO2 catalyst had been changed. Then, test these samples in the selective oxidation of cyclohexane with molecular oxygen in the solvent free system. Under the reaction conditions of 150 °C and 1.0 MPa O2, BaCO3-CeO2 presented 10.5% conversion of cyclohexane and 85.0% selectivity of KA oil within 2 h. Beside, a plausible catalytic mechanism for the selective cyclohexane oxidation using BaCO3-CeO2 catalyst and O2 as oxidant was proposed. This work describes the synergistic effect between the Ba and Ce on the cyclohexane oxidation and might provide a facile strategy to design the catalyst for cyclohexane oxidation reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)2·6H2O, AR) and barium chloride dihydrate (BaCl2·2H2O, AR) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial China and Xilong Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., respectively. Urea (CO(NH2)2, AR) was obtained from RHAWN Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. All chemicals were used directly without further purification, and deionized water (DI water) was used in all of the experiments. BaCO3-CeO2 composites with various molar ratios of Ba/Ce (denoted by BaCO3-CeO2-X, where X represents the molar ratio of Ba/Ce for feeding) were synthesized by the one-pot direct hydrothermal treatment method. In a typical synthesis procedure, a certain proportion of Ce(NO3)2·6H2O (2, 5 or 8 mmol), BaCl2·2H2O (8, 5 or 2 mmol) and urea (10 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of water and stirred at room temperature for 30 min to obtain a homogeneous solution, then the mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 24 h. The solution was cooled to room temperature and the powders were isolated, washed three times with water and ethanol, following dried in an oven for 12 h at 80 °C. Subsequently, the powders were calcined at 700 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 2.5 °C/min under air atmosphere to form the BaCO3-CeO2-0.25, BaCO3-CeO2-1 and BaCO3-CeO2-4. For comparison, pure CeO2 and BaCO3 were also treated under the same experimental conditions. 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the prepared materials using a RigakuSmartLab system to clarify phase and crystal structure. The stationary X-ray source was Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) with the scanned angles (2θ) from 5° to 90° and scanning rate of 10 °C/min. Elemental analysis was obtained using ICP-OES (Shimadzu ICPE-9000). Determination of weight loss and phase transition temperature was analyzed by TG and DTA (SeikoTG/TGASSC5000). The heating rate was 10 °C/min to 800 °C. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was record by Thermo Scientific Nicolet-380 from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1. Raman spectrometer (Renishaw inVia) was equipped with UV–Vis CCD detector and Leica DMLM to recorded Raman spectra. SEM was carried out by using JEOL JSM-7800 (Prime) equipped with energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), the samples were coated by gold before obtaining the micrographs. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on QuantaChrome ASAP 2460 at 77 K. The pore size distribution was calculated from the adsorption branch using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. The surface area of the catalysis was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra was taken on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi system. . The binding energies (BE) were calibrated by using the C 1s peak (BE = 284.8 eV) as the standard. Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were investigated in the Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 equipped with a TCD detector. Typically, 40 mg catalysts were pretreated at 120 °C for 0.5 h, cooled to 50 °C, and then the catalysts were heated to specified temperature in the 10% O2/Ar, 10% H2/Ar atmosphere or in the 10% CO2/Ar conditions. 2.3 Catalytic performance Catalytic performance study was carried out in the selective oxidation of cyclohexane using O2 as oxidant at 150 °C. Firstly, 0.1 g of the catalyst and 10 g of the cyclohexane were charged to a 100 mL sealed Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. Then, the reactor was flushed with a stream of pure oxygen to replace air at least three times. After the temperature reached approximately 150 °C, the reactor was filled with the desired amount of oxygen (1.0 MPa). Under magnetically stirring (600 rpm), the reaction carried out for 2 h and cooled to room temperature in an ice water cooling system. After the reaction, the catalyst particles and the solution were completely transferred to centrifugal tube using methanol. The catalysts were removed by centrifugation and the supernatant was filtrated to test. The concentration of cyclohexanol (A), cyclohexanone (K), cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide (CHHP) were analyzed by a SHIMADZU Gas Chromatograph (GC-2010-plus, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.50 µm InertCap-WAX capillary column) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using chlorobenzene (0.3 g) as the internal standard. The CHHP was calculated using the difference of cyclohexanol before and after adding 0.1 g triphenylphosphine (PPh3). The main by-products, adipic acid (AA), glutaric acid (GA) and succinic acid (SA), were detected by esterification using heptanoic acid (0.08 g) as the internal standard. The solution that had been analyzed for K, A and CHHP removed light components, such as cyclohexane, by rotary evaporator at 40 °C. Then, both the concentrated liquid and residual liquid in flask washed by methanol were transferred to centrifugal tube. The homogenized solution (2 mL) and concentrated sulfuric acid (1 mL) were introduced into a 25 mL pressure resistant glass tube equipped with PTFE plug at 100 °C for 1 h. Typically, 5 mL of DI water and 3 mL of dichloromethane were added to the tube for extracting after cooling to room temperature. The lower solution was used for testing the esters (dimethyl heptanoate, dimethyl adipate, dimethyl glutarate, dimethyl succinate) after esterification by GC. Obviously, the amount of substance of the four different esters is the same as the corresponding four types of acid. On account of numerous complex products in the reaction solution, the complete analysis for the reaction mixture is not straightforward. Thus, the conversion of cyclohexane (mol%) and selectivity of all products were calculated according to the following formulas: conversion ( % ) = [ A o ] − [ A t ] [ A o ] × 100 Where [Ao] is the initial cyclohexane concentration (in moles), [At] is the concentration of cyclohexane after 2 h. selectivity ( % ) = [ product ] [ A o ] − [ A t ] × 100 Where [product] is the concentration of a mono-oxygenated products (in moles) after 2 h and Σ[product] is the summation of concentrations of the entire products. The value of [Ao] - [At] is equal to Σ[product]. The stability study was carried out by removing the spent catalyst from the reaction mixture through centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol three times respectively, dried at 80 °C in an oven for 12 h, and then used for the next run under the same catalytic conditions. Importantly, cyclohexane was reduced with the loss of catalysts for the following cycles to maintain the same proportion of catalysts and reactants. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the prepared BaCO3-CeO2 composite catalysts 3.1.1 Crystal structure and textural properties The XRD patterns of the CeO2, BaCO3-CeO2-X and BaCO3 samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. XRD patterns of the CeO2 catalyst exhibited four strong diffraction lines at 28.6, 33.1, 47.5, and 56.3°, which are associated with the CeO2 faces (111), (200), (220), and (311) (PDF#81–0792) [29,30]. With the continuous increase of Ba content, the diffraction peaks of BaCO3 phase (PDF#71–2394) were detected at 23.9° and 24.3° [31]. Meanwhile, the diffraction peak intensity weakens with the decrease of the relative content of cerium ion. In addition, compared to pure CeO2, a small pattern shift to lower 2θ value was observed with the BaCO3-CeO2 (Table S1), this may be due to the phenomenon that the Ba2+ (0.135 nm) has bigger ion radius relative to Ce4+ (0.101 nm) [32], a number of Ba2+ enter the crystal phase of CeO2 and cause lattice distortion, which leads to the change of fluorite structure of CeO2 [33]. In order to further characterize the structural characteristics of the catalyst, the catalysts were explored by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in the Fig. 1b, the band at around 467cm−1 is ascribed to the F2g mode of the fluorite phase CeO2 [34]. With the increase in the BaCO3 content, the F2g vibration slightly shifts toward lower wavenumbers, and the peak becomes smaller, indicating that certain amount of Ba can be incorporated into the CeO2 lattice and caused lattice distortions, which consistent with the data obtained by XRD in Table S1. These results indicate that lattice distortion or residual stress exists in the BaCO3-CeO2 samples, which can activate molecular oxygen and offer lattice sites for migrating oxygen [35]. FT-IR spectra of CeO2, BaCO3-CeO2 composite and BaCO3 materials showed in Fig. 1c. The absorption bands attributed to the vibrations in CO3 2− are located from 1800 cm−1 to 400 cm−1 [36]. There is an obvious absorption peak at 1432 cm−1, indicating the existence of carbonate in the catalyst, and then it is determined that BaCO3 exists in the catalyst [37]. Peaks at 1059 cm−1 is assigned to the bending in the symmetric stretching vibrations [38]. The absorption peak at 855 cm−1 is attributed to the out of plane bending vibration of C-O bond in barium carbonate [39]. With the increase of barium content, the corresponding carbonate absorption peak intensity increases gradually. The infrared characterization results show that the content of BaCO3 on the surface increases with the adding amount of barium. The micro-structure and morphology of catalysts are obtained from SEM. The morphology of pure CeO2 is leaf flake, which can be seen in SEM image in Fig. 2 a. However, after adding BaCl2 in the preparation process, the morphology of the catalyst changed significantly. Evidently, with the increase of BaCO3, the morphology changes from flake to cluster and then to block. The elemental mapping presented in Fig. 3(f) states clearly that Ce and Ba species were evenly distributed in BaCO3-CeO2-1, indicating that the composite has been formed. Hydrothermal synthetic system provides a suitable crystal growth environment to the control the concentration and diffusion of CO3 2− for the formation of cauliflower-like BaCO3-CeO2-1. With the 150 °C of hydrothermal temperature, urea will decompose to produce NH3 and the pH value rises gradually, which can also provide the necessary microenvironment for release CO3 2− homogeneously [40]. Furthermore, when the CO3 2− reaches saturation, Ce3+ and Ba2+ interact with CO3 2−, the crystal nucleus is formed rapidly, the grain grows, and stops growing after reaching equilibrium. Ce2O(CO3)2·H2O and BaCO3 could be obtained from XRD in Figure S1 [41]. Finally, the final products of CeO2 and BaCO3 are gained after calcination at 700 °C and the Quality degradation of TGA result is depicted in Fig. 3 a. The chemical reactions involved are as following: CO ( N H 2 ) 2 + 2 H 2 O = 2 N H 4 + + C O 3 2 − ( 1 ) 2 C e 3 + + B a 2 + + 2 O H − + 3 C O 3 2 − = C e 2 O ( C O 3 ) 2 . H 2 O + BaC O 3 ( 2 ) C e 2 O ( C O 3 ) 2 . H 2 O + 1 / 2 O 2 = 2 Ce O 2 + 2 C O 2 + H 2 O ( 3 ) Additionally, the textural properties and porous nature of the BaCO3-CeO2-based catalysts are evaluated in Fig. 3b. and summarized in Table S1 through N2 adsorption desorption experiment at 77 K. The specific surface area is calculated by the calculation formula of BET method, and the specific pore volume and pore diameter data are obtained by BJH model. It is interesting that the CeO2, BaCO3-CeO2–0.25 and BaCO3-CeO2–1 possessed a characteristic type IV sorption isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loop [42], including a sharp capillary condensation step at P/P0 = 0.4–0.5 and most of the hysteresis rings appear in the high-pressure region, that is, the relative pressure P/P0 is in the range of 0.45–0.95. When the content of BaCO3 is low, the specific surface area becomes larger than that of pure CeO2. This may be due to the fracture of CeO2 structure caused by a small amount of BaCO3, which can be seen in Fig. 2b. While with the increase of BaCO3, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases gradually, which is mainly caused by the surface covering and pore plugging effect of the Ba salt introducing in cerium dioxide. This is also consistent with the gradual evolution of the BaCO3-CeO2 composite with the increase of BaCO3 content observed in SEM. 3.1.2 Surface properties In order to further investigate the changes of valence state and relative content of elements on the surface of catalyst after introducing BaCO3, the samples were measured by XPS spectra. For the XPS spectra of Ce 3d, Fig. 4 a can be observed that there are four groups of characteristic peaks of Ce 3d at 882, 885, 889, 898, 900, 902, 907 and 916 eV, which are labeled as u1, v1, u2, u3, u4, v2, u5 and u6 respectively. u1, u2 and u3 belong to the 3d3/2 spin orbit multiple spectral line of Ce4+, u4, u5 and u6 belong to the 3d5/2 spin orbit multiple spectral line of Ce4+, v1 and v2 belong to the spin orbit multiple spectral lines of Ce3+ 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 [43–45]. The Ce species in the catalyst samples of CeO2, BaCO3-CeO2-0.25, BaCO3-CeO2-1 and BaCO3-CeO2-4 mainly exist as Ce4+, but the reduced Ce3+ can be observed. According to the corresponding peak intensity, the content of Ce3+ in the catalyst sample doped with BaCO3 is much higher than that in pure CeO2 in Table S2. This is because the introducing of BaCO3 makes part of it enter into the CeO2 lattice, which makes the structure and morphology of CeO2 change, resulting in the reduction of part of Ce4+ to Ce3+, and the existence of Ce3+ leads to the imbalance of catalyst surface charge, which is easy to cause lattice defects and conducive to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies [46,47]. Compared with the other catalysts, the content of Ce3+ in the reduced state of sample BaCO3-CeO2-1 is the highest. In the O 1s spectra (Fig. 4b), three different characteristic peaks are discernible at 529.3, 530.4, and 532.0 eV, which are assigned to the lattice oxygen atom (Oα), surface oxygen species (Oβ), and carbonate and hydroxyl species (Oγ), respectively [48]. Oβ is considered to have higher catalytic activity than other oxygen species due to its high mobility [49]. The content of Oβ on the surface of pure CeO2 is relatively lower compared with BaCO3-CeO2-X. It shows that the surface adsorbed oxygen content contained in BaCO3-CeO2-1 is the highest, and the change trend of surface adsorbed oxygen content is consistent with that of Ce3+. Additionally, the two main binding energy peaks at 780.0 and 795.3 eV are associated with Ba 3d3/2 and Ba 3d5/2 [50], respectively. Meanwhile, the peak at the bond energies of 789.2 eV belongs to the loss features of Ba [51]. With different amounts of Ba introduced, the peak position red shifts are different, which can be observe in Fig. 4c and Table S2. This may be affected by the low electronegativity of Ba (0.89) to lose electrons easily, which leads to a higher Ce3+ content on surface of BaCO3-CeO2-1. Therefore, the shift of the Ba 3d peak here should be attributed to the electronic interaction between BaCO3 and CeO2 and the electron interaction of BaCO3-CeO2-1 is relatively strong. O2-TPD measurements could further explore the oxygen species of the catalysts. The peaks at a lower temperature correspond to the desorption of oxygen species, such as peroxides and super oxides adsorbed on the catalyst surface, while the desorption peaks of lattice oxygen generally appear at a higher temperature. Additionally, the peak intensity and desorption temperature are related to both the amount and the properties of surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ), which might affect the catalytic activity [52,53]. In Fig. 5 a, the O2 desorption temperature gradually shifts to low temperature range with the increase of barium content. Notably, the intensity of desorption peak increased first and then reduced, and BaCO3-CeO2-1 had the largest peak area. It indicated that the most active BaCO3-CeO2-1 catalyst with lager peak area and relatively low peak temperature, which was more preferable for O2 dissociative adsorption and easier to produce active oxygen species on the surface. Therefore, it could be concluded that the amount of adsorbed oxygen might be enhanced by changing the mount of BaCO3, which was also consistent with the XPS results. The redox characteristics and active species of the catalysts were observed depending on H2-TPR experiment in Fig. 5b. Three representative catalyst samples (BaCO3-CeO2–0.25, BaCO3-CeO2–1 and BaCO3-CeO2–4) were tested by H2-TPR. Different amounts of BaCO3 will affect the reduction ability of CeO2. The profile of the BaCO3-CeO2–1 could be deconvoluted into TPR peaks at 399.5 and 470.6 °C, which are attributed to the reduction of surface cerium to trivalent cerium and trivalent cerium to cerium [54]. However, the reduction peak of BaCO3-CeO2–0.25 is at 501.5 °C, and the reduction peaks of BaCO3-CeO2–4 are at 496 °C and 635.2 °C. Obviously, when the X is 1, the reduction peak of surface Ce4+ obviously shifts to lowest temperature, and the H2 consumption of the reduction peak also increases significantly. Therefore, BaCO3-CeO2–1 has stronger redox ability compared with the other two catalysts. This shows that adding certain amount of BaCO3 is conducive to the reduction of surface oxygen in CeO2. The result may due to the strong intermetallic interaction between BaCO3 and CeO2, which enhanced the redox ability of the catalyst. Further, CO2-TPD was used as a measurement technology to evaluate the typical alkaline density and alkaline intensity of the catalysts though CO2 desorption amount and desorption peak temperature respectively [33]. Fig. 5c could be noted that alkalinity was affected by the amount of BaCO3. The weak basic site was the predominant form in the CeO2 catalyst, and there was a CO2 desorption peak around 120 °C. Meanwhile, a medium-strength basic peak centered at 300 °C was observed, indicating that there was a moderate intensity of surface CO2 desorption peak. It should be noted that with increasing the content of BaCO3, the amount of weakly alkaline and moderately alkaline decreased or even disappeared. The main reason for this phenomenon was that BaCO3 did not show alkalinity. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the BaCO3-CeO2 composite catalysts To verify the role of CeO2 and BaCO3 species and clarify the reaction process, two compared experiments of different reaction time have also been tested in Fig. 6 a and b. Compared to the pure BaCO3, the reaction induction period was reduced by 30 min and CHHP decomposition can be found over the pure CeO2. After prolonging the reaction time to 3.5 h, the deep oxidation did not occur significantly. Nevertheless, the conversion of less than 1% cyclohexane was increased by prolonging the time to 3.5 h. Contrary to CeO2, the conversion of pure BaCO3 is low and the content of CHHP is high at the initial stage of the reaction, which indicates that the reaction has a long induction period and speculates that BaCO3 can possibly control the O-O bond breaking. With reaction time prolonged from 2 h to 3.5 h, the byproducts of diacid (AA, GA and SA) increased by 10.6 times over BaCO3, indicating that the reaction was prone to deep oxidation. Therefore, the catalytic capacity of ceria can be further improved by adjusting the amount of BaCO3. Take advantage of the characteristics of the two catalysts to give consideration to the conversion and Ka oil selectivity. In the following experiments, 2 h was determined as the most suitable reaction time in this catalyst system. Table S3 summarizes that the resulting conversion and selectivity performances of various catalysts at 150 °C and the data were plotted in Fig. 6c. It could be observed that the conversion of cyclohexane and the selectivity of products were varied for different catalysts. For the single metal compound catalysts, CeO2 exhibited 2.6 times more than its counterpart BaCO3 in conversion. Nevertheless, in terms of conversion, CeO2 was at least 24% lower than the CeO2 and BaCO3 composite. BaCO3-CeO2–1 showed the best catalytic activity and a conversion of 10.47% was achieved with, suggesting a synergistic effect between the two metals of Ce and Ba. However, as the molar ratio of Ce and Ba changes, the conversion decreases to 9.10% and 9.12% for BaCO3-CeO2–0.25 and BaCO3-CeO2–4, respectively. These results signified that proper proportion influences the cyclohexane conversion. The relation between Ce3+/Cetotal, Oβ/Ototal, and the conversion attained on studied catalysts is displayed in Fig. 7 a. For the cerium containing catalysts, a volcano-shape characteristic was obtained in the cyclohexane conversion, which is similar to the change trend of Ce3+/Cetotal ratio. The BaCO3-CeO2–1 catalyst with the highest Ce3+/Cetotal ratio (19.9%) possessed the best conversion (10.47%) by activate C-H bond. Furthermore, the Oβ species is considered to have higher surface reactivity of an oxidation reaction than the lattice oxygen and other oxygen species because of its high mobility. The content of oxygen adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 catalyst sample is relatively low. With the introduction of BaCO3, it is found that the content of Oβ in the sample BaCO3-CeO2–1 increases greatly, however, when the introducing amount of BaCO3 further increases, the content of Oβ in the catalyst sample BaCO3-CeO2–4 is relatively BaCO3-CeO2–1samples low. This shows that the Oβ content contained in BaCO3-CeO2–1 is the highest, and the change law of Oβ content is consistent with the variation law of Ce3+. The high contents of Ce3+ and Oβ along with the oxygen vacancies were responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity of BaCO3-CeO2–1. The significantly decreased cyclohexane conversion (9.70%) and selectivity for KA oil (74.34%) were observed over simple mechanically mixed catalyst (Table S3), which added the same proportion as the ICP-OES test results of BaCO3-CeO2–1. The results showed that the interaction between CeO2 and BaCO3 was beneficial to improve the activity and selectivity of the reaction. In addition, CHHP decomposition is another key step for the cyclohexane oxidation [55]. It is found that as BaCO3 increased, CHHP selectivity increased from 1.35% to 49.08%. The decomposition ability of CHHP is related to whether the O-O bond is easily broken, further affecting the selectivity of KA oil. Therefore, CeO2 is beneficial for CHHP decomposition, while BaCO3 is unfavorable for CHHP. By analyzing the basicity of the catalyst, alkaline environment of CeO2 are the key to CHHP decomposition, which was revealed in Fig. 7b. It is obvious that alkaline strength is negatively correlated with CHHP selectivity. In other words, the stronger the alkalinity is, the more conducive to the decomposition of CHHP. Alkaline sites interacted with weak acidic CHHP to weaken the strength of O-O bond, leading to efficient decomposition of CHHP. Zheng provided a new strategy for synthesizing α-Co(OH)2 nanoplatelets for CHHP decomposition with alkaline microenvironment, tunable wettability and interlayer spacing in alkali-free medium [56]. Cerium oxides with various particle sizes and shapes have been synthesized and used for CHHP decomposition [25]. In addition, NaOH is required commonly as an additive in industrial production for CHHP decomposition. The CHHP can react with OH− in alkaline aqueous phase to obtain cyclohexyl peroxy anion, which transfers from cyclohexane phase to alkaline water phase quickly due to the coulomb gravity, and collides with catalysts in the decomposition reactor to generate activated complex, thus reducing the activation energy of decomposition reaction. Therefore, alkaline sites may be the main factor for CHHP decomposition. To probe the reaction pathway, the influence of reaction time for the reaction over BaCO3-CeO2–1 catalyst was showed in Fig. 6d. The cyclohexane conversion liner increased as the reaction time increased. At the same time, the decreased selectivity for CHHP, the increased selectivity for KA oil and others (AA, GA, SA) were observed. Interestingly, the selectivity of cyclohexanol remained unchanged from 0.5 h to 2 h, while cyclohexanone selectivity had been increasing. It can be speculated that after CHHP is decomposed into KA oil, A is the main product, and a small amount of K may be formed, which would deeply oxidized to produce other acid by-products. The relative dynamic balance of K selectivity is maintained. In addition, a possible reaction pathway over the BaCO3-CeO2–1 catalyst was depicted in Fig. 7c. The oxidation reaction of cyclohexane is a free radical reaction [57], while cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide is the intermediate product to synthesize cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone [5]. Firstly, cyclohexane is activated by tetravalent cerium in the catalyst to form cyclohexyl radical. At the same time, trivalent cerium is oxidized to tetravalent cerium by oxygen. The activated cyclohexane reacts with oxygen to form cyclohexyl peroxide radical, which is then transformed into cyclohexyl radical and cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide under the effect of cyclohexane. Finally, cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide is further decomposed into cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone under the action of catalyst. To better illustrate the advantages of prepared catalyst, the reaction conditions and catalytic performance were compared to the reported heterogeneous catalysts, which was shown in Table 1 . Through analysis, it was found that shorter reaction time, lower temperature and oxygen pressure may improve KA oil selectivity, however, the cyclohexane conversion was inefficient. Compared with molecular sieve, carbon materials, other metal oxide catalysts, the present solvent free catalyst system could achieve excellent KA oil yield with O2. Moreover, the one-step, low cost of the synthesis procedure adds an additional advantage to use this catalyst. These results clearly show the BaCO3-CeO2–1 is a promising catalyst in cyclohexane solvent-free selective oxidation of cyclohexane. Recycling tests were carried out for BaCO3-CeO2–1 catalyst and the results were presented in Figure S2a. Apparently, the conversion and the selectivity to KA oil were changed slightly after five runs, demonstrating the BaCO3-CeO2–1 catalyst behaved remarkable stability. The characterizations of used the recyclable test had been provided in Figure S2b and c. XRD showed that the catalyst composition was still CeO2 and BaCO3. However, the obvious decrease of the diffraction peak intensity of BaCO3 may be caused by the acidic environment. Otherwise, in the Figure S2c, FT-IR results indicate that the bands from 1100 cm−1 to 1300 cm−1 that indicate the presence of C-O bonds. In addition, the bands that could be assigned to the presence of C-H groups at 2850 and 2930 cm−1 and in the 1300–1500 cm−1 region can be found in spent catalyst. These results confirmed that the existence of carbonaceous deposits with oxygen functional groups on the catalyst surface after the consecutive runs [21], which could not be removed by centrifugation and washing. Therefore, the acidic environment leads to the decrease of barium carbonate crystallinity, and the carbonaceous deposits were adsorbed on the catalyst surface because of high temperature and high pressure, which may be the reasons for the slight decline of catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of BaCO3-CeO2 composite has been prepared and showed excellent catalytic activity in the oxidation of cyclohexane to KA oil by using O2 as oxidant. When the molar ratio of Ce to Ba is 1:1, the optimal proportion of the composite (BaCO3-CeO2–1) could be obtained. The conversion of cyclohexane and the selectivity of KA oil was achieved 10.5% and 85.0%, respectively. Furthermore, the good performance of BaCO3-CeO2–1 was attributed to the high content of the surface Ce3+ species and Oβ, which could generate most oxygen vacancies to aid in the C-H bond activation of cyclohexane and activate molecular oxygen. Moreover, the basic site may be the pivotal reasons for promoting CHHP decomposition effectively. The high reactivity of BaCO3-CeO2–1 may attract the interests of researchers to probe its potential in the selective oxidation of other hydrocarbons to produce the value added chemicals. coredata.dc:description: BaCO3-CeO2 composite catalysts were prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis method, and the influence of Ba/Ce on the structural and catalytic performance for selective oxidation of cyclohexane with molecule oxygen was studied. The characterization results exhibited that the doping amount of BaCO3 would influence the morphology, the content of surface Ce3+ and surface oxygen species (Oβ), and alkalinity. Meanwhile, the amount of alkali is the key to the decomposition of cyclohexyl hydrogen peroxide (CHHP). 10.5% conversion of cyclohexane and 85.0% selectivity of KA oil were achieved under the reaction conditions of 1.0 MPa O2 and 150 °C for 2 h. The excellent catalytic activity was attributed to its high atomic ratios of Ce3+/Cetotal and Oβ/Ototal on the surface and optimal redox capacity.
coredata.dc:title: High performance BaCO3-CeO2 composite catalyst for solvent-free selective oxidation of cyclohexane with molecular oxygen
